textRegions.text: What is Disruptive about Online Work?

The Bernard L. Schwartz Globalization Initiative at SAIS Distinguished Lecture Series
November 8th, 2012
Marketplace for work that can be done remotely
E.g., computer programming, graphic design, data entry, writing & translation
oDesk takes 10% of the wage bill
Aside from wage arbitrage, what’s driving this growth?
Ever-improving (often free) technology making geography less relevant
Global proliferation of low-cost, high-bandwidth IT
Technological innovation allowing employment-like relationships not just arms-length contracts
Economists have long-recognized that employment is not like arms-length contracts

“Inputs” problem partly fixable with tech
oDesk has a digital punch-clock or “Work Diary”
Employers can “watch” workers work
Possibility of employment creates a global labor market
Possibility of employment creates a global labor market
Anyone in the world can employ anyone else in the world, regardless of geography.  That’s a big change.
Literature in economics trying to estimate magnitude
However, traditional view of outsourcing/offshoring is occupation-specific
However, traditional view of outsourcing/offshoring is occupation-specific
However, traditional view of outsourcing/offshoring is occupation-specific
We could also decompose by skill at occupation level
We could also decompose by skill at occupation level
We could also decompose by skill at occupation level
We could also decompose by skill at occupation level
We could also decompose by skill at occupation level

Gains from labor specialization, 
comparative advantage, etc.

Gains from labor specialization, 
comparative advantage, etc.

Smith: Specialization limited to the extent of the market
Global market for labor could allow extreme specialization
Though extreme specialization requires great matching technology
There is a very tight labor market in engineers in Silicon Valley
Are online and traditional workers substitutes or complements?

What characterization dominates?
Access to online workers could make the SF programmer more productive, increasing demand
Is online work viable a development strategy?
There are enormous purely place-based differences in real wages
States ensure that law of one price does not prevail
Gains from more liberal immigration policies are likely to be huge, but...

Source:  “The development impact of a best practice seasonal worker policy”
by John Gibson and David McKenzie
Can scalable online education build human capital needed for this work?
Emergence of “scalable” education models & tools for autodidacts
